awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Elucidation of Maspardin Function and its Role in the Endocytic Pathway
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual merit. Animals need to interact and respond to their environment in a timely fashion and they do so by the activity of neurons.  Neurons are highly specialized cells that integrate multiple stimuli and conduct information in the form of fast electrical impulses. This information often must travel great distances, such as down the length of the spinal cord.  Maintenance of neuronal function requires highly coordinated protein synthesis and subsequent movement to their proper intracellular location.  A newly identified protein, maspardin, is thought to in part play a critical role in this intracellular trafficking process.  The research goal of this project is to examine maspardin's contribution to BMP signaling, ligands belonging to the transforming growth factor superfamily, as well as growth factor receptor signaling and/or trafficking; to investigate whether disruption of signaling events following maspardin depletion alters intracellular machinery function such as Rab7 a widely expressed GTPase, important for trafficking, development and fusion of endocytic vesicles, and to identify novel maspardin interacting proteins.  

Broader impacts. The activities associated with this project will increase student interest and success in science by engaging students from a rural regional university in meaningful research on a wide range of molecular and cellular techniques. Research activities include gene cloning, bacterial protein expression and purification, mammalian culturing techniques, siRNA induced gene knockdown, SDS-PAGE and western blot analysis, protein-protein interaction identification, microscopy and 2D Differential Gel Electrophoresis.  Scholarly activities include technical research, critical thinking, and effective presentation and improved writing skills.  Advancement of the research and developing a well-structured mentoring program will increase further participation of student?s involvement in research throughout the department, improve faculty involvement and benefit all involved.  Current and future students will be better prepared for careers in scientific inquiry by participation in applied research.  Targeted students include women, Hispanic, African-Americans, and other groups underrepresented in STEM fields.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the proposal were to: 1)  advance scientific knowledge about novel mechanisms and pathways during normal tissue formation and differentiation in vivo and in vitro, 2)  lay the ground work for a robust and dynamic research environment focused on using cutting ­edge molecular, cellular, and developmental biology approaches to better understand intracellular trafficking and normal cell structure and function and events that lead to differentiation of cells and tissues,  3)  integrate these activities with the education of undergraduate and M.S. level graduate students by providing broad opportunities for research in cellular, molecular and developmental biology, thus enabling a connection between didactic and practical studies of biological problems with the goal of better preparing and encouraging students for entry into doctoral programs.

The original research focused on studies of a protein essential for normal nerve development and function, Maspardin. A mutation in the Maspardin gene in humans leads to Mast Syndrome, a complicated form of inherited spastic paraplasia and corresponding dementia. A maspardin knockout mouse (where normal marspardin is no longer produced) was developed, and studies to determine the mechanisms of action were conducted in this animal model.

With progression of the project, the focus was expanded also to include broader opportunities for student involvement in cutting edge research projects related to neurobiology and cardiovascular biology that would lead to publications and presentation opportunities. These opportunities for student involvement encouraged them to go on in their research areas of interest to pursue Ph.D. and other doctoral degrees. With regard to cardiac development, students were able to work with a chemical from the body, a specific ribonucleic acid (RNA), which has the ability to convert non-muscle cells into cardiac muscle cells in tissue culture. The future value of this basic cell and molecular biology research might lead to being able to use this RNA to treat patients who have had heart attacks by repairing the damaged muscle in their hearts.

The main goal of the educational components of the research were to increase the number and diversity of US students pursuing careers in science. This was achieved by: 1) involving undergraduates in high ­quality scientific research experiences and expanding on the PI's and collaborating faculty's strong records of mentoring undergraduates in research, 2) enhancing a mentoring program for undergraduates, 3) providing mentored experiences involving undergraduate and master-level graduate students in research while preparing them for Ph.D. and professional programs in biological sciences.

Insights and knowledge generated by the research will continue to benefit both the scientific and public communities as the research projects have already contributed to an understanding of what cells require to differentiate normally. The educational activities have increased student interest tremendously and success in science by exposing students to scientific  content they would not normally have access to, increasing research interests of undergraduate students by providing high ­quality research experiences, and improving the success of undergraduates by developing a well ­structured mentoring program targeting females, Hispanics, African ­Americans, and other groups under represented in STEM fields. Significant amounts of training and professional development were accomplished during the course of the award.

Many opportunities for training and professional development were provided by the project. Over the past years, students have gained significant experience in a variety of morphological, molecular and biochemical experimental protocols and learned how to handle and work with rodent animal models to analyze the effects of neurodegeneration with respect to behavior, morphological and physiological characteristics. The undergraduate students also have learned a variety of cellular and molecular biology methods (microscopy, tissue culture, immunofluorescent and confocal microscopy, electrophoresis, RT-PCR, molecular cloning and sequencing, etc.). In addition, studies were performed to explore factors affecting and directing the differentiation of induced pluripotent stem cells and other non-muscle cells (e.g., fibroblasts) to form into cardiac muscle or nerve cells. Several students co-authored papers and one served as a co-inventor on a patent. In addition, many of the undergraduate students ended up doing  honors theses through the Honors College Program and their thesis often resulted in a co-authored publication for the student in a peer-reviewed journal.

Thus, the opportunities for training and professional development provided by this NSF RUI grant to our students have been tremendous. Numerous students who would not have had an opportunity to participate in major world-class, publishable research projects were able to do so. In addition, it has become clear that these research experiences significantly enhanced the careers of the students by helping them to gain admission to Ph.D., D.V.M. and M.D. programs at major research universities. Definitely, the career opportunities for students who were part of the NSF RUI program have been significantly increased. It has been a tremendous success here at Texas A&M University-Commerce, and we are most appreciative of the NSF providing this very significant support to enrich our students’ research experiences. 


Last Modified: 03/31/2017
Modified by: Larry Lemanski
